wikipedia_page.main: Gerald Graham 'Graham' Peel (1877—November 1937) was an English composer.

response: Among other cycles composed during the period before World War 1 were the four Songs of A Shropshire Lad  by Graham Peel and the six for voice and piano in A Shropshire Lad: A Song Cycle (Op. 22, 1911) by Charles Fonteyn Manney (1872–1951).Lieder Net Archive George Butterworth was particularly drawn to Housman's poems, composing within a short period the Six Songs from A Shropshire Lad (1911) and Bredon Hill and Other Songs (1912) as well as his emotive Rhapsody, A Shropshire Lad, first performed in 1913.Hold 2002, pp. 236–41 Butterworth was killed during the war, but towards the end of it Ivor Gurney was working on the songs in his cycle, Ludlow and Teme (1919),Kate Kennedy, "Ambivalent Englishness: Ivor Gurney's song cycle Ludlow and Teme", First World War Studies, Volume 2, 2011, – Issue 1: Literature and Music of the First World War and later went on to compose the eight poems in The Western Playland (1921).Lieder Net archive Ernest John Moeran was another combatant in the war and afterwards set the four songs in his Ludlow Town (1920).

Several poems were set to music during Ogilvie's lifetime, including by famed English composer Graham Peel with 1920 'The challenge'.  Slim Dusty's 1980 The man who steadies the lead song compilation acknowledged two of Will's works – the self-titled album and The pearl of them all.  Ogilvie's verse was also put to music by bush poet Gary Fogarty, of Millmerran, Queensland, with thirteen poems on The Tartan Saddlecloth in 2005.CD The Tartan Saddlecloth: Performing the bush verse of Will Ogilvie (2008), produced by www.restlessmusic.com.au.  Fourteen tracks.  Scotland's Hawick-based 'folk-and-roll' band Scocha set several of Will's poems to music, and continued by the restructured and renamed group as 'Harden Blades'.

Scottish Border poet and Australian bush balladeer Will H. Ogilvie (1869–1963) wrote the 'The gipsies' (c. 1910; and later put to music by British composer Graham Peel), having been raised  away.  Ogilvie also wrote a song for the 'Coronation of the Gipsy King at Yetholm' by July 1898 whilst in Australia.
* "Reveille", art song on the Housman poem by Graham Peel (1877-1937)

Among Walker's students were Herbert Murrill, Reginald Jacques, Victor Hely-Hutchinson, Sir Thomas Armstrong, Graham Peel, Sir William McKie, Robert Still, and Gervase Hughes.
